poems.text:
A single granite slab rests on the workshop floor—  
rough edges softened by hands that dream beyond the stone.  
Each chip, a whisper of patience; each polish, a promise  
to craft not merely surfaces but stories.  

From distant waters, a boy once crossed,  
his pockets light, his vision vast,  
seeds of hope in the soil of foreign lands,  
where opportunity waits in the spaces between struggle and chance.  

The pivot comes suddenly—  
not in the triumphs sung aloud,  
but in the quiet hours of doubt,  
when courage is the last grain lodged beneath the nail,  
and fear stretches long shadows toward the dawn.  

Here, in this moment, the future is forged—  
not in gold or fleeting acclaim, but in trust,  
built frame by frame with steady hands and steadfast hearts.  

A legacy is not a monument on a hill;  
it is the tree that grows beyond the planter’s eyes,  
rooted deep in unseen ground,  
stretching into a canopy where others find shade.  

And so the work continues—  
not to conquer, but to nurture,  
not to stand alone, but to reach outward,  
for lasting craft is love made tangible.  

In the quiet gleam of polished stone,  
I see the story still unfolding:  
success is the journey home.

A slab of granite, cool beneath calloused palms,  
cut from earth’s slow patience,  
its veined surface a map of enduring time.  
Manu saw beyond this weight, this stone—  
a foundation not for walls but for futures,  
each block a seedling in the wilderness of want.  

The journey was not linear—  
a pivot at the crossroads where doubt lurked,  
fear’s shadow brushing against hope’s flame.  
In that moment, resolve did not falter;  
it crystallized like quartz, sharp and clear—  
a steadfast promise to build not just business,  
but bridges of trust and opportunity for those unseen.  

Hands worn by labor, eyes bright with dreams,  
he learned that legacy is more than monument—  
it is the quiet work of lifting others,  
the invisible mortar binding lives.  

From India’s soil to the shores of tomorrow,  
where every milestone is a step forward,  
and every challenge a teacher’s gift,  
he planted not only roots but wings.  

Because to build something lasting is to give away  
the very stones you hold,  
so others may craft their own horizon.
